suggestion:
Summary (100 words):

Students found the lecture on Excel, particularly histograms, to be the most interesting part of the class. They appreciated the hands-on experience of creating and formatting histograms in Excel, as well as the discussion on when to use different types of graphs for various data sets. Many students found the in-class assignment and breakout room discussions helpful in understanding the material, and enjoyed learning how to work with Excel to analyze and visualize data. They also appreciated the opportunity to practice using Excel and receiving feedback from their peers and the instructor.

Suggestions:

1. Consider rephrasing the summary to focus more on the Excel-specific skills that students gained, such as "Students gained hands-on experience with creating and formatting histograms in Excel, and learned how to apply different types of graphs to various data sets."
2. Emphasize the students' appreciation for the interactive nature of the class, such as "Students enjoyed the in-class assignment and breakout room discussions, which allowed them to practice using Excel and receive feedback from their peers and the instructor."
3. Consider adding more specific details about the Excel features that students found most useful, such as "Students appreciated the ability to edit bins and bin width in Excel, and learned how to use histograms to display frequency of data."
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students gained hands-on experience with creating and formatting histograms in Excel, and learned how to apply different types of graphs to various data sets. They appreciated the interactive nature of the class, including in-class assignments and breakout room discussions, which allowed them to practice using Excel and receive feedback from their peers and the instructor. Students also valued the ability to edit bins and bin width in Excel, and learned how to use histograms to display frequency of data, making them more confident in their ability to analyze and visualize data using Excel.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the breakout room sessions to be a valuable and engaging part of the lecture, allowing them to collaborate with their peers, ask questions, and receive help from the instructor. Many appreciated the opportunity to work together on assignments, share ideas, and discuss topics in a more interactive and dynamic environment. The breakout rooms provided a sense of community and support, making the learning experience more enjoyable and effective.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the carbon footprint calculations and activity to be a thought-provoking and engaging part of the lecture. Many were surprised to learn that their individual carbon footprint is higher than expected, and some were shocked to discover how many "earths" would be required if everyone lived like them. The use of a website to calculate their carbon footprint was a valuable learning experience, allowing students to see the impact of their daily choices on the environment. Additionally, the discussion on trade-offs and the ethical considerations of engineering in the context of climate change sparked interesting conversations and reflections.
input:
Solar panel specs
I found the site that calculated how many earths we would need if everybody lived like me very interesting and I do not know how they calculated that.
I found our footprint to be most interesting because it is crazy to think that we use that much energy as an individual.
I found that it was interesting that my carbon footprint is much higher than I expected.
working with my team
I found that the amount of carbon that a car with “good gas mileage” was interesting because it seemed large.
I found the use of ethics in engineering interesting 
The images of change website was very interesting with regards to how it included man made and natural changes in the environment.
I found my environmental footprint interesting.
Calculating our carbon footprints and finding out how many earths would be required if everyone lived like we did was very interesting.
 I thought the footprint activity was really interesting to see how many earths I would need if everyone lived like me. I thought it was a really cool for everyone to see that so people could make changes to their daily lives!
 I really liked the part of class where we were able to see what our carbon footprint and greenhouse gas emissions were.
 I found the website that found my carbon footprint very interesting today.
 The most interesting part of today's class was using a website/survey to figure out your own carbon footprint. It was interesting learning how much damage we are each doing individually to our environment.  Hopefully through engineering we will reduce our carbon emissions.
 I thought that the carbon footprint calculator was very interesting. 
 I found how engineers have to take ethics into consideration with things like climate change interesting. I also found the different slides showing glaciers and ice melting very interesting. The contrast was something I was not expecting in the pictures shown during class.

 I just enjoyed working on the solar project. My group had some problems to work out relating to the assignment, and those were enjoyable to solve.

 I found the class activity the most interesting. This was because it involved our own lives with our own cars.
 I found calculating our own carbon footprint interesting, as well as looking at the before and after pictures.
 I enjoyed learning my car had a mpg of 24, I thought it was Better than that. Also the trade offs and the responsibilities of an engineer to protect the wellbeing of the community without saying “but it costs too much”.
 looking at the climate change photos and assessing my own impact 
 I thought it was cool that we found our carbon footprint and that we also calculated what our car's carbon footprint is. I also liked that we got so much time to work on the assignments, it really helps us to be on the same page with everything.
 I found it interesting how well I did on the exam. I was really proud of my work. 
 I found interesting how large my carbon footprint is. I might play around with the website later.

pred: SUMMARY: The breakout rooms were a highlight of the lecture, allowing students to interact with their peers in a more intimate setting. Many students appreciated the opportunity to meet new people and form connections with their classmates. The breakout rooms also facilitated in-depth discussions and allowed students to share their thoughts and ideas with others. Some students found it interesting to see the diverse perspectives and interpretations of what an engineer in 2030 would look like, and appreciated the chance to engage in meaningful conversations with their peers. Overall, the breakout rooms were seen as a valuable tool for building class camaraderie and fostering a sense of community.
input:
I found the class to be interesting and interactive. I enjoyed meeting fellow students as this helped me to feel more comfortable and overall welcome in the class.
The class activity was interesting. 
Getting to know the professor and the peers
I loved the breakout rooms and the chance to meet new people. I also found the activity we did very interesting as well because I didn't expect the questions you asked us afterwards to be so thought-provoking. 
I liked how we went over what the course would look like and who we could contact for help.
I found the breakout groups to be the most interesting. I had never used them before so it was a good learning experience.
I enjoyed the breakout sessions. They really allowed me to talk more in-depth with specific people, rather than just watching the instructor. It made the whole experience a lot more initiating and interactive. 
The people I met in my group 
I thought that the layout of the course was interesting and the activity of drawing our view of an engineer was very interesting. The layout is 4 main projects and I thought that it was cool to be in that format rather than many smaller projects. The drawing was interesting because it made you look to the future.
The most interesting thing I found was the logistics of the class and how we are supposed to complete projects
 I found the most interesting thing in today's class was the discussion we had with our breakout group about how engineers in 2030 would be like.
 I found the understanding of how the general aspects of the class would work to be interesting in today's class.
 I found the projects and specifically the design project most interesting in class. 
 The interaction between the class, as well as what the content of the course is going to be. The breakout rooms were useful in getting to know the other students.
 Talking to my breakout group and meeting some of the class. 
 How we will get to work in teams, I want to get better at the collaboration.
 How many people did not draw an engineer in a lab.
 using the breakout rooms and getting to meet other people.
 I found the structure of the class to be most interesting. Most of my classes are a “go at your own pace” so it's really refreshing to actually have the professor and others there to help answer questions.
 i liked learning about the breakout sessions 
 The future of engineering as drawn by today's engineers.
 I am new to the zoom breakout rooms and I like how simple it will be to create teams and meet with them.
 I thought the activity where we drew what an engineer would look like in 2030 was very interesting. I also thought the breakout groups were very fun and interesting since I didn't know that was a feature on zoom.
 I think the way class is organized will be enjoyable and I am excited to begin!
 I found it interesting how we got a chance to meet other people right away. I also think that doing a drawing the first day to look back later is pretty cool too. 
 Talking to people about the future of engineering and what they wanted to do. It was also nice to see what out first project is going to be
 The slides with information on how to write a professional email, as that is new information for me.

 I found icebreaking and drawing very fun. 
 I found it interesting that many people changed their majors for engineering after this class. I also thought it was interesting that we are able to learn about all the different branches of engineering!

 I found the draw an engineer activity interesting

 The drawing activity with predicting a future engineer. 10 years isn't too distant, but humans tend to be very bad predictors of what the future will hold.

 The professor being from Turkey was pretty interesting to me, I've never met someone from Turkey.

SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion with various aspects of calculations, including the use of formulas, variable identification, and mathematical modeling. Some students found it challenging to apply formulas to real-world problems, such as calculating the height of a pipeline and pressure head. Additionally, there were difficulties in understanding how to derive mathematical equations from tables and how to create mathematical models, particularly with the laminar approach. Some students also struggled with identifying the correct variables and numbers to use in calculations, and a few found the in-class assignments and participation activities confusing due to unclear instructions.

Suggestions:
1. To address the confusion with variable identification, provide more explicit examples of how to match variables with numbers in calculations, such as in the pipeline height and pressure head problems.
2. Offer more detailed explanations and examples of how to derive mathematical equations from tables, particularly for the laminar approach, to help students understand the underlying mathematical concepts.
3. Provide clearer instructions for in-class assignments and participation activities, including specific examples of what is expected and how to approach the tasks, to reduce confusion and increase student understanding.

3. To address the confusion about citation requirements, consider providing a more in-depth explanation of APA style notation and offering additional resources for students to learn more about proper citation.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on engineering failures to be a compelling and thought-provoking topic, with many reflecting on the importance of ethics, communication, and attention to detail in preventing catastrophic failures. The Taum Sauk reservoir case study was a notable example, with students highlighting the consequences of negligence, oversights, and cost-cutting measures that led to the disaster. Many appreciated the opportunity to work in groups and analyze real-world examples of engineering failures, which helped them understand the significance of diligent and accountable engineering practices. Overall, the topic sparked a sense of caution and awareness among students, emphasizing the need for careful consideration and thorough analysis in engineering projects.
input:
I enjoyed the discussion about engineering failures. I wish we had spent more time on discussing what choices resulted in the failures.
I found the engineering failures for the Taum Sauk reservoir to be an insightful example of how engineering projects can go badly based on negligence and lack of proper ethics by engineers involved in orchestrating it.
What I enjoyed most in this class was working on the project with my peers.
Learning about different engineering disasters and going into detail about how things went wrong was interesting 
i thought constructures experts make can also be fallen
It was a straightforward and informational lesson with work time, and thus did not have much interesting or now knowledge. 
I found it interesting that such little flaws in engineering design or communication can lead to such drastic and catastrophic failures of mechanisms and projects. It really shows the importance of good communication, documentation, and considering all possible perspectives.

These examples helped highlight the important of team communication and keeping track of what you have done and still need to do.

Summary: Students found the discussion on the Tom Sauk Reservoir to be a compelling example of engineering failures due to negligence, lack of proper ethics, and oversights in design and communication. Many students were fascinated by the reservoir's flawed construction, which led to catastrophic consequences, and appreciated the opportunity to analyze the various reasons behind its failure. The discussion highlighted the importance of good communication, documentation, and considering all possible perspectives in engineering projects. Students also enjoyed working in groups to research and discuss the reservoir's failure, which helped them understand the significance of diligence and accountability in engineering.

Suggestions:

1. To make the summary more concise, consider removing the phrase "due to negligence, lack of proper ethics, and oversights in design and communication" as it is implied in the phrase "flawed construction." This would make the summary more focused on the topic of the Tom Sauk Reservoir.
2. To further emphasize the significance of the discussion, consider adding a sentence highlighting the real-world implications of the reservoir's failure, such as the damage to the environment and the impact on the community.
3. To make the summary more engaging, consider starting with a more attention-grabbing sentence, such as "The Tom Sauk Reservoir's catastrophic failure served as a stark reminder of the importance of careful planning and attention to detail in engineering projects."
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: The Tom Sauk Reservoir's catastrophic failure served as a stark reminder of the importance of careful planning and attention to detail in engineering projects. Students found the discussion on the reservoir to be a compelling example of engineering failures due to its flawed construction, which led to catastrophic consequences. The discussion highlighted the importance of good communication, documentation, and considering all possible perspectives in engineering projects. Students appreciated the opportunity to analyze the various reasons behind its failure and enjoyed working in groups to research and discuss the reservoir's failure, which helped them understand the significance of diligence and accountability in engineering.

pred: SUMMARY: Many students found Assignment 10 and the in-class activity to be confusing, citing unclear instructions, particularly regarding the technical brief, mathematical modeling, and the Laminar Approach. Some students struggled with understanding how to find reliable sources, citing, and interpreting data. Additionally, some students felt that the in-class activity was unclear, and the time allocated for it was insufficient. There was also confusion surrounding the specific requirements for parts 4 and 5 of the assignment, as well as the expectations for the final submission.
input:
It was all pretty clear, there wasn't much that I was confused about in this lecture
Everything was clear over the material that was discussed in class
What was confusing about this class, was how are we supposed to know if to include something we think is a  constraint is one for the company too?
The expectations for Assignment 10 were very unclear. During our studio time it took us a very long time to understand what exactly was "due" on the technical brief.
Today, I thought that the instructions for assignment 10 were confusing, especially involving the mathematical modeling for the project.
I was confused around the in class activity. How do you find peer reviewed or reliable sources on more general information. All papers seem to be on specific topics.
The Taum Sauk upper reservoir sketch for the tech brief was confusing because it did not detail  what the sketch was entailing when it came to calculations.
Parts 4 and 5 of assignment A10 are very confusing. My team and I have all read the “background/technical content” several times. We are still unclear on how to draw the visual models using the Laminar Approach. I believe that going over the Laminar Approach and doing an example would be extremely beneficial to all teams. 
I didn't really understand which sources were acceptable for this class. I know which sources are more reliable than others, but not which degree of reliability is acceptable for class assignments. 
I didn't have enough time for the in class activity. Also what we were supposed to do in the second  time in breakout rooms wasn't completely clear to me.
 i was having wifi problems at the beginning of the class so the discussion at the beginning was confusing.
 I was confused because on A10 we have to split up the work but you can't do parts 5-7 until 4 is done. 
 Everything explained was clear.
 I was somewhat confused as to if the scholarly summary needed to be a full paragraph or if 2-3 sentences could suffice. 
 I think that the documents for homework are some times confusing because the instructions are not the clearest 
 Explanation for what the client memo was outlining
 since there wasnt much info today, I didn't find anything confusing
 Something that needed more detail in today's class was the explanation of how hydroelectric plants create greenhouse gases.
 The beginning of the assignment talking about mathematical models
 N/A
 The directions for A10 weren't as clear as they could have been, since it wasn't noted at the beginning that A10 was only half of the Taum Sauk Reservoir project.
 My group had some confusion figuring out exactly what needed to be done for the assignment. 
 What i felt was confusing in todays class was the premise of the in class activity. When the in class activity was assigned I was confused about what exactly needed to be completed regarding the questions.
 Nothing in today's class was especially confusing.
 Nothing
 Mathematical models for Taum Sauk project were confusing because we didn't have enough information about what was expected.
 I am confused how the laminar approach works. 
 I was unsure as to what the mathematical models were used for and how they should be made in A10. I think if you were able to give some more overview or background of the assignment before we were sent into breakout rooms that could help
 The citation part was confusing. 
 A bit on how to calculate the volume for the resevoir, that was difficult for my team and I to figure out.
 How the catme survey worked and where it was available.
 I thought that the information about methods of finding reliable information was difficult. I would have appreciated more time being spent on it and some more examples being given.
 Nothing was confusing really everything was pretty clear. 
 The confusing part about today was figuring out how to cite my source during the in class activity. It was confusing to determine if the article that I picked out was a journal, website, excerpt, etc. The APA citation itself wasn't that hard; just figuring out which way to cite my source was.
 While working on assignment 10, it said something about the “laminar approach” and I'm not sure what that is.
 Something that was confusing in today's class was how to do the in-class assignment, I wasn't sure where to do the assignment until I read the description you put in the zoom chat. 
 I would like for you to explain parts 4 and 5 of assignment 10 a little more in depth as just reading it was a bit confusing. I think it was hard to understand because I didn't understand exactly what it meant by mathematical models. 
 I needed more time to do the in class assignment. I always run out of time in the assignments that are due in class, and this leaves me behind during the class.
 Laminar approach in the A10 assignment was a little difficult to understand
 the new project a10 was pretty confusing and I want some more info about it
 I feel as though I took in all the information and wasn't necessarily confused by any particular part of today's class. 
 There wasn't anything too particularly confusing in today's class meeting, however, I did find the introduction discussion on the reservoir information to be a little brief. I was slightly confused about how this specific reservoir worked, however, the in class activity did end up resolving this.
 Maybe we could have gone over how hydroelectric power works a little more before talking about the Taum Sauk reservoir.
 How much does our CATME score rating affects our peers grades
 Part V of Tech Brief is really confusing 
 One subject that needed a little more elaboration would be information literacy. It was confusing because I needed a little more info on in text citations.
 I found what sections we are supposed to do in the the assignment, especially what a laminar approach is. I do not know how to compute this. 
 Nothing was confusing to me today.
 Something that needed a little more clarification was probably the different ways of searching for reputable sources. 
 I didn't find anything about this lecture confusing.
 How to search for data quickly.
 The models for assignment A10 needs some explaination for clarification.
 What is the procedure for having only 3 members in a group?
 Our teammates and I were take hard time to realize what is the goal of the assignment 10. It will be appreciated more clear explanation about assignment.
 Nothing was confusing. Everything was well explained. 
 The assignment instructions for A10 were a little confusing, but talking it over with the team cleared things up. I think the information about citing and using scholarly sources was clear and helpful. 
 I didn't find anything confusing today.
 It would be helpful to have more details about the Sauk project and what we need to do for each milestone.
 What type of graph the assignment wants us to do. Also how to interpret the data
 I was confused on parts of assignment A10
 I was confused as to whether the walls of the dam sloped inward or outward.
 Although I was not confused on anything, I did feel like the agenda of the meeting covered a lot of information, which made me feel a little overwhelmed. However, after discussing with my group, I was able to clarify any questions and concerns.
 I was confused on the Catme calibration necessary for assingment 9. I simply submitted my survey and responses, but was confused on whether I had to calibrate first or not. I'm just hoping I did it right.
 Not much of anything was very confusing. The one thing I would label as confusing would be that on bright space it says that a10 is due at class 5a and you said it was due 5b.
 I needed more details on the assignment 10 and what should be the final thing to turn in for that
 nothing 
 What was a bit confusing was the source searching part of class. I understand that using google and Wikipedia is only good for generic searches, but using all scholarly sources can be problematic when trying to find general information. I was just confused because it sounds like we can't use these sources, but scholarly ones are too specific. 
 how to use the outside resources information in the research 
 I was confused about if you wanted us to only use google scholar articles,i also was confused about assignment 9 mainly because i joined a bit after the meeting had started due to wifi issues. I also was confused about how much that was needed to be written for he in class assignment.
 Something that needed more detail in today's class is the specific parts of the assignment (A10). Information on Laminar Flow and other topics that others may not know about can be explained, even if briefly, to help give a general idea of the topic to the students.

Suggestions:
1. Provide a more detailed explanation of the Laminar Approach and its application to the project, including examples or a step-by-step guide, to help students understand how to apply it to the visual models.
2. Clarify the expectations for the visual models in Assignment 10, including what specific calculations or information should be included, to reduce confusion and ensure students are on the right track.

They were fascinated by the potential of solar energy to produce electricity, its increasing cost-effectiveness, and the various ways it can be harnessed. Students also appreciated the emphasis on unit conversions and the importance of considering multiple factors when evaluating energy production. Many found it intriguing to learn about the statistics of efficiency for solar panels and the impact of location on payback. Overall, students are excited to explore the benefits and challenges of solar energy through the assigned project.

Suggestions:

1. To make the summary more concise, consider removing the phrase "with many expressing enthusiasm" and rephrase it to "expressed enthusiasm" to directly incorporate the sentiment into the sentence.
2. The phrase "real-world applications of the subject" could be rephrased to "real-world applications of solar energy" to make it more specific and focused on the topic.
3. Consider removing the phrase "the benefits and challenges of solar energy" from the last sentence and rephrase it to "the assigned project's focus on solar energy" to make it more specific and focused on the project.

They were fascinated by the potential of solar energy to produce electricity, its increasing cost-effectiveness, and the various ways it can be harnessed. Students appreciated the emphasis on unit conversions and the importance of considering multiple factors when evaluating energy production. Many found it intriguing to learn about the statistics of efficiency for solar panels and the impact of location on payback. Overall, students are excited to explore the assigned project's focus on solar energy.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on car carbon emissions to be a fascinating topic, particularly the calculation of their own vehicle's emissions. Many were surprised by the significant amount of CO2 produced by their cars, with some mentioning the Corolla's 260 grams of CO2 per mile as a notable example. The in-class activity of calculating car emissions and the use of online tools to determine personal carbon footprints were also highlighted as engaging and informative. The connection between car emissions and the broader impact on the environment, including climate change, was a recurring theme, with students expressing interest in learning more about the importance of considering environmental effects in their future projects.

SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on car carbon emissions to be a fascinating topic, particularly the calculation of their own vehicle's emissions. Many were surprised by the significant amount of CO2 produced by their cars, with some mentioning the Corolla's 260 grams of CO2 per mile as a notable example. The in-class activity of calculating car emissions and the use of online tools to determine personal carbon footprints were also highlighted as engaging and informative. The connection between car emissions and the broader impact on the environment, including climate change, was a recurring theme, with students expressing interest in learning more about the importance of considering environmental effects in their future projects.

Suggestions:

1. Emphasize the students' personal connection to the topic: While the summary mentions that students found the topic fascinating, it would be more effective to highlight specific quotes or statements from students that demonstrate their personal connection to the topic, such as "I would have never thought it was that much" or "I'm glad it was covered in today's class period".
2. Quantify the impact: To make the summary more impactful, consider including specific numbers or statistics about the average CO2 emissions of cars or the environmental impact of car emissions. This would help to reinforce the significance of the topic and make it more relatable to the students.
3. Highlight the design trade-offs: The original summary mentions that students found the discussion on design trade-offs interesting, but it would be more effective to explicitly connect this to the topic of car carbon emissions. For example, you could mention that students appreciated learning about how engineers must consider trade-offs when designing vehicles to minimize their environmental impact.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on car carbon emissions to be a fascinating topic, particularly the calculation of their own vehicle's emissions. Many were surprised by the significant amount of CO2 produced by their cars, with some mentioning the Corolla's 260 grams of CO2 per mile as a notable example. The in-class activity of calculating car emissions and the use of online tools to determine personal carbon footprints were also highlighted as engaging and informative. Notably, students expressed a personal connection to the topic, with some stating that they "would have never thought it was that much" and others expressing gratitude for the discussion, saying "I'm glad it was covered in today's class period." Students appreciated learning about the importance of considering environmental effects in their future projects, including the need for design trade-offs to minimize car emissions.

The in-class activity of calculating the carbon emissions of their vehicles was particularly engaging, with many students noting that they were surprised by the significant amount of CO2 produced by their cars. The concept of trade-offs was also a recurring theme, with students appreciating the idea of weighing the pros and cons of different design choices and their environmental implications. Overall, the topic of carbon footprints resonated with students, who saw its relevance to their future careers as engineers and the need to address the climate crisis.

refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students found the discussion on carbon footprints to be a highlight of the lecture, with many expressing interest in learning about the environmental impact of their daily activities and the importance of considering this in their engineering projects. Specifically, several students noted that they were surprised by the significant amount of CO2 produced by their cars, with one student stating that their Corolla produced 260 grams of CO2 per mile, "which is actually quite a bit." The in-class activity of calculating carbon emissions was particularly engaging, with students appreciating the hands-on approach to understanding their personal carbon footprint. The concept of trade-offs was also a recurring theme, with students appreciating the idea of weighing the pros and cons of different design choices and their environmental implications, as one student noted, "I found the discussion on design trade-offs very interesting." Overall, the topic of carbon footprints resonated with students, who saw its relevance to their future careers as engineers and the need to address the climate crisis.

This could be emphasized to show the relevance of the topic to the students' field of study.
3. Consider breaking down the summary into two separate paragraphs, one focusing on the students' interest in learning about climate change and their personal carbon footprint, and another on the in-class activities and their effectiveness in engaging students. This could make the summary more concise and easier to read.

pred: SUMMARY: Students generally felt that the details regarding assignments, particularly Assignment 8, were unclear or confusing. input:
Discussing the calculus formula for finding the area was a bit confusing. I would've liked a bit more information about it, and how it works.
the assignment number 5
I felt all the details were clear during this class
One thing that was confusing about today's class was how to switch the x-axis to a percentage from a numerical value in the skittle example. I was just confused as to if there is an easy way to change it or if that is just something you have to calculate and then set as a new type of data. 
We needed more details about what we were using the class' skittle data for. There is already a PDF of skittle data for Assignment 08 so what was our data for?
Today I thought that assignment 8 was confusing. I was struggling with how to handle the missing data in excel.
How was the data on people age gathered from Excel? I thought that many of the birth dates where redundant.
Bike share group project.
The z score was roughly explained

How probability and z score are related. Also, can we please go over some examples of how to fill in missing data. My team is struggling on question one on assignment 8. Could we go over some examples of how to fill in missing data? 
 I feel A08 needed more explanation. When we talk in class about assigments ensemble we do that superficially but when we need to work on them on out own or with our team I start to feel a little bit lost.
 What we were supposed to be doing in the first breakout room was confusing because we were just sitting around for most of it and we didn't know what to do.
 Nothing was confusing today during class
 I think I need more practice with the concepts of probability and standard distribution of data.
 I didn't understand where the .06 value for the standard deviation came from
 The due dates are alittle confusing in bright space so maybe a better expiration on how to find things better 
 The explanation for what to do for assignment 08
 How to decide how similar distribution s are to the normal distribution and when to use the z-score. 
 I wasn't really confused today
 Assignment 5 because we did not go over it.
 The material for A08 seemed like it needed a little extra detail since the module as a whole doesn't seem to have much discription.
 I find probability in general confusing. 
 I felt like the explanation regarding the process of finding the probability of a skittles bag having over 27% yellow skittles. 
 The z score was a little bit confusing. I did watch the module prior to class, however it still throws me off. I understand the concept behind it but feel I would like more practice and work with it. 
 I would've appreciated more time spent on the expectations for each assignment, such as a read through of the instructions and the expectation for each point.
 Something I found unclear about today's lecture was how the z number was used in the calculus equation for area under the curve.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the concept of biomimicry, or using nature to create solutions to design problems, to be a unique and interesting approach to problem-solving. Many students were fascinated by the examples presented in class, including the use of snake skin patterns to improve road safety and the strong, force-resistant shells inspired by beetle shells. Students also appreciated the opportunity to brainstorm and generate ideas using various methods, and were excited to apply these skills to their design project. Overall, the topic of biomimicry sparked curiosity and enthusiasm among the students, with many finding it to be a valuable and relevant concept in engineering.
input:
It was interesting seeing how humans are making technology that mimics animals.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the topic of carbon emission to be highly engaging and relevant, particularly when it came to understanding the impact of their personal and vehicle-related carbon footprints. Many appreciated the hands-on activities, such as calculating their car's CO2 emissions and using online tools to determine their personal carbon footprint. The discussion on design trade-offs and the importance of considering environmental factors in engineering projects also resonated with students. The visual aids, including images and websites showcasing the effects of climate change, helped to drive home the significance of addressing carbon emissions. Overall, the topic sparked interest and awareness among students about the role of engineers in mitigating the climate crisis.

pred: SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion regarding the prototyping process, particularly in relation to testing. Many students struggled to understand how to effectively test their prototypes, especially when working with virtual models created using CAD software. Some students questioned the feasibility of testing without physical prototypes, while others were unsure about the level of detail required for their prototypes. Additionally, students were unclear about how to develop a testing protocol and measure the success of their experiments.
input:
Today's class was little confusing and I didn't need any extra details.
Prototyping 
The prototype section, specifically testing, is VERY confusing. My team is unsure how we are supposed to test our prototypes, especially if they are created using CAD software. Without purchasing materials, I'm unsure what could be used to create and test our solutions.
How detailed we need to be in our prototypes. 
Finding ways to develop a prototype for our idea 
I was confused about how to make a prototype for one of our designs originally. 
Nothing was confusing in today's class
I didn't get what materials i should use for prototype 
Something that could use more details in today's class was the schedule with our new reading day, because you went over it kind of quick and I didn't catch all the dates. 
We as a team found it difficult to find out not only how we would build a prototype, and how to test it. Unless we make them individually, physical prototypes aren't really feasible due to our separation. Additionally we couldn't figure out doable but also reliable ways to test our prototypes. 
 I thought the most difficult aspect of today's class was determining how to prototype our ideas to show the functionality of them.
 How we should develop a testing protocol is unclear. I don't remember going over it in the video modules and it isn't explained in the technical brief or assignment 17 instructions. I think going through an example of a testing protocol for the smart recycling bins would have been beneficial to the teams' understanding of what a testing protocol is and how to develop an effective one. 
 The confusing part about today was figuring out how my group will make the prototypes and test them in life. This was confusing for us because one of our team members is off campus, so we need to figure out how to test the prototypes and how we are making them.
 Everything made sense into today's class. But I wish there was more explanation to the ways we could create prototypes if the software option was not available to use. Other than that, everything made sense.
 I found it interesting the different types of modeling that could be used
 What was confusing was how the prototypes the groups create will be tested. My group was having a hard time understanding how this would be done virtually and with models of our design (given we don't have the ability to make real models of our prototype with the materials we wanted)
 The details for the assignment was confusing to me. The team was confused on what CAD software to use and some of the other elements of the assignment. I think after the slides are posted we will be able to review it and answer our questions.
 A confusing thing was the building of prototypes. It was confusing because of the use of materials that aren't easily accessible. 
 I am unsure of when A18 is due because bright space still has it down for next Friday. But it was said that we will work on it next Friday in class as well.
 I think prototyping in general is a bit confusing, at least to me. I dont really know how should I approach prototype making. 
 It was a little confusing how we are supposed to test our prototypes without actually having physical prototypes. My group is doing CAD models, and are having difficulty determining how we are going to effectively test our models, as they aren't really something we can just go out and test.
 How we can test our ideas was confusing because our ideas must be used on such a large sclae and we have such limited materials.
 I did not completely understand how through our prototypes had to be.
 Nothing was confusing or hard to understand. Everything was very clear 
 I haven't been exposed to a lot of the prototyping methods like CAD, so I feel like it might be pretty tough to learn something like that in the next week. 
 I thought it was confusing when we talked about the surveys because I was unsure if they counted as part of the prototype testing process. 
 I wasn't confused about anything today. We just had a few hiccups with our last grade and discussed with the TA what we got wrong.
 I thought that the discussion of the importance of prototyping was interesting. It had good information and was easy to follow.
 How we should go about testing any physical model that we create
 I would've appreciated if we went over some examples of what a strong experiment looks like versus a weak one. Additionally, how we could measure if our experiments were successful.
 I am confused on how to exactly test my virtual prototypes. 
 Knowing how to prototype virtually can be difficult and confusing at times, and having useful accessible materials is not always possible.
 One thing that was confusing about today's class was how are we supposed to test our design on a virtual platform if the platform only allows you to design not test? Or do you have to make the physical prototype and then test?
 I found it confusing how we are going to create a prototype for some of our designs
 I was a bit confused still on how detailed we needed to make our prototypes especially since we don't always have the resources
 What options we would have for making prototypes. If there were things we are not allowed to do on campus that would limit what we can do. 
 How in depth the experiments should be
 I was confused as to how to actually test a prototype. 
 Nothing today 
 nothing was confusing
 The research method and way of testing was confusing. Nothing was clarified.
 More details about the testing procedure section would be helpful 
 Thinking of prototypes while most of our ideas had to do with the road was confusing
 Nothing was confusing today. There was nothing to be confusing though because everything explained had to do with methods of prototyping.
 We only had one confusing point during the lecture, we didn't understand if it was supposed to be 3 different designs or 3 different ideas prototyped. This was solved however in our breakout room 
 Nothing was confusing today! Professor Menekse explained the prototyping process well, which helped us to discuss ways to make prototype our designs
 Everything was clear and easy to understand
 How we should make a prototype that we can also test, for example cad models would be hard to test for a18.
 Nothing
 the specifications of assignment 18 needed a bit more clarification, but otherwise all was pretty clear 
 I was confused by the way we can implement questions for the concrete details

suggestion:
SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion regarding the prototyping process, particularly in relation to testing. Many students struggled to understand how to effectively test their prototypes, especially when working with virtual models created using CAD software. Some students questioned the feasibility of testing without physical prototypes, while others were unsure about the level of detail required for their prototypes. Additionally, students were unclear about how to develop a testing protocol and measure the success of their experiments.

Suggestions:
1. Emphasize the importance of clarifying the testing protocol and providing examples of effective testing methods, such as the smart recycling bins example, to help students understand the process.
2. Provide more guidance on how to test virtual prototypes, including the use of CAD software, and offer suggestions for accessible materials or alternatives for students who do not have access to physical materials.
3. Offer additional support for students who are struggling to understand the level of detail required for their prototypes, such as providing a rubric or guidelines for prototype development.
refined_pred: REFINED SUMMARY: Students expressed confusion regarding the prototyping process, particularly in relation to testing. Many students struggled to understand how to effectively test their prototypes, especially when working with virtual models created using CAD software. To address this, it is essential to provide clear guidance on developing a testing protocol, including examples of effective testing methods, such as the smart recycling bins example. Additionally, offering suggestions for testing virtual prototypes and providing accessible materials or alternatives for students without physical resources will be beneficial. Furthermore, offering a rubric or guidelines for prototype development will help students understand the level of detail required for their prototypes, ensuring a smoother prototyping process.

pred: SUMMARY: Students found the prototyping aspect of the lecture to be the most engaging and interesting part of the class. Many students appreciated the hands-on experience of brainstorming and working with peers to generate ideas and solutions, as well as learning about various methods and tools for prototyping, such as CAD software and 3D printing. Students also enjoyed exploring different materials and services available for prototyping, including those offered by Purdue's ITAP. Additionally, the process of creating prototypes and testing their effectiveness was seen as a valuable learning experience, allowing students to make informed decisions and refine their designs.

pred: SUMMARY: Students gained a deeper understanding of Red-Black Binary Search Trees (RBBST), specifically the properties and operations involved. They grasped the concept of maintaining a balanced tree with a total number of black edges to any leaf node being the same, and the worst-case runtime of theta(log(n)) for all operations. The class also explored the insertion process, including the three states it can transition through to correct any temporary violations of RBBST conditions, and the use of rotation (left and right) to balance the tree.

SUMMARY: Students found the Right Hand Rule to be a source of confusion, particularly in determining the direction of magnetic fields when multiple currents are involved. Many students struggled with understanding which finger to use for the rule and how to apply it to different scenarios, such as counter-clockwise flowing loops of current. Some students also found it difficult to determine whether magnetic fields would cancel out or amplify each other. The reversibility of the Right Hand Rule and its application to more complex problems, such as systems with multiple unknowns, was also a point of confusion.

Suggestions:

1. Clarify the finger usage for the Right Hand Rule: The summary mentions that students are unsure about which finger to use for the rule, suggesting that a clear explanation of the finger usage would help alleviate this confusion. This could be done by explicitly stating which finger corresponds to which component of the magnetic field or current.
2. Provide more examples of Right Hand Rule application: The summary highlights that students struggle with applying the Right Hand Rule to different scenarios, such as counter-clockwise flowing loops of current. Providing more examples and practice problems that demonstrate the application of the rule in various situations would help students become more confident in their understanding.
3. Emphasize the relationship between magnetic field direction and cancellation: The summary notes that students are unsure about whether magnetic fields will cancel out or amplify each other. Emphasizing the relationship between the direction of magnetic fields and how they interact with each other would help students better understand this concept and apply the Right Hand Rule more effectively.

Additionally, students found it challenging to apply the rule to different scenarios, such as counter-clockwise flowing loops of current, and determining whether magnetic fields would cancel out or amplify each other. Furthermore, students were unsure about the reversibility of the Right Hand Rule and its application to more complex problems, such as systems with multiple unknowns. Clarifying the finger usage and providing more examples of Right Hand Rule application will help alleviate these confusions and enhance students' understanding of the concept.
